This is useful when you want to handle the “no match” case explicitly without providing a fallback.

code: var optionalFeature: String? // Can be nil
// @Decides - always returns a value with fallback

inlineContent.text: A property wrapper that evaluates decision specifications and returns an optional result without requiring a fallback.
. It evaluates decision specifications and returns the result if a specification is satisfied, or
if no specification matches. This is ideal when you want to explicitly handle the “no match” case without providing a default value.
when no specification matches instead of requiring a fallback
: Generic over both context and result types
: Cleaner API when you want to handle
: Supports arrays, decision specs, and custom logic
: Create complex decision trees with fluent API
Detect when no specification matched (explicitly handle
Conditionally apply logic only when criteria are met
Distinguish between “no match” and a default value
Implement optional routing or content variants
The wrapper evaluates specifications in order and returns the first match or

code: // Only enable if user is in experiment
// If nil, skip experimental features entirely

inlineContent.text: The key difference is how they handle “no match”:

code: // @Maybe - returns nil when no specification matches
var optionalFeature: String?  // Can be nil
enableFeature(feature)  // Only runs if spec matched
// @Decides - always returns a value with fallback
let feature = guaranteedFeature  // Always has a value

inlineContent.text: has meaning (feature disabled, no match, skip logic)
when you always need a value (routing, tier selection, configuration)

code: return "Upgrade now to continue using premium features"
return "Did you know premium users get..."
// Show help after 30 seconds on complex screens
// Record that we sent this email

inlineContent.text: Create complex optional decisions with the builder API:

code: // Both are nil if no spec matches
// No flag set - should be nil
// Disable flag - should be nil again
// Disable premium, beta should now match
var badContent: String?  // VIP users get public content!
// let content = banner!  // Crashes if nil!
// Use @Maybe when nil means "don't do anything"
// If nil, don't apply any theme
// Use @Decides when you always need a value

inlineContent.text: : Place most likely matches first for better performance
: Context retrieved once per property access
: No caching; evaluates on each access

abstract.text: A protocol for specifications that can return a typed result instead of just a boolean.
This extends the specification pattern to support decision-making with payload results.
A context object that holds data needed for specification evaluation.
This serves as a container for all the information that specifications might need
to make their decisions, such as timestamps, counters, user state, etc.
The projected value, identical to
for Maybe.
Both provide the same optional result.
A property wrapper that provides declarative specification evaluation.
A property wrapper that evaluates decision specifications and always returns a non-optional result.
A decision specification that evaluates child specifications in order and returns
the result of the first one that is satisfied.
A mock context provider designed for unit testing.
This provider allows you to set up specific context scenarios
and verify that specifications behave correctly under controlled conditions.
Platform-independent core for building specification-based business logic in Swift.
The optional result of the decision specification.
Returns the result if a specification is satisfied,
otherwise.
A property wrapper for asynchronously evaluating specifications with async context providers.
A property wrapper that evaluates decision specifications and returns an optional result.
